description: The Red Lobster of nightclubs.  This is the only "club" that Matt will consider going to and I don't go clubbing without hubby, so I'm between a rock and hard place.  More cheese than a large pizza.  Whateva -- I have Wii Dance Revolution if I want to party!! LOL!!
author: Sherylle W.

description: I guess that the Starlight Room is doing very well financially because they don't seem to need any extra business.  I left a message for them to call me back because I was interested in planning a birthday party there.  I never got a call back.  When I decided to call again I talked to the manager and he finally got the guy who handles the private events on the phone for me.  The whole attitude turned me off.  Yes he answered my questions but I thought that he was going to fall asleep because he was so bored talking to me.  Needless to say I won't be going here.
author: C. K.

description:
Cool. Great view. Expensive drinks. They apparently have food, which is probably overpriced. Yadda yadda. I'm not *dying* to come back, but I'd probably recommend it to visitors.

I have a friend in high places (do expatriate techno DJs count as high-place people?) who was performing here one night. I credit him for getting us out on the "balcony" (a fire escape with a nice view where the employees take breaks), so that was pretty cool. The crowd that night was meh (techno ain't really my thing), but the atmosphere of fans + older tourists still didn't bug me.

I give it props for being nice and old-worldy inside, with tons of pictures of Harry Denton and all the famous people who hit up his bar back in the day. Cocktail (just the one at $12 a pop) was good; Cointreau and rum concoction was tasty, but nothing exceedingly special.

it seems like Top of the Mark is their biggest fancy-drink-old-world-bar competition, so I'd still head there first if I'm in the area and looking for an old bar with a view.
author: Tara R.

description: Weird experience but overall a good one. Met up with some friends here while visiting San Francisco on a Saturday night. The crowd was ollder but the music was young. Me and my friends danced and had fun, also got great views of Union Square from the dancefloor. However, it took forever to get a waitress or a drink and like the other posts I had to check my card because initially they overcharged me about $25. I checked a couple days later and it was corrected. Also, was not pleased they said the door charge was $5 and when we got upstairs they raised it to $10, they were only giving free admission before 9 and to hotel guests.
author: Enisha B.

description: Wow. So rude and inconsiderate! I'm shocked. The owner/manager was defending his belligerently rude server. Can never come here again sadly.
author: C C.

description: Maybe the place has a great atmosphere and a stunning view of the city, but even combined those certainly doesn't compensate the terrible service that can only be described as pretentious and unorganized. The "manager" that was huffing and puffing around seemed more like he was monitoring a hot dance club roof bar, but someone needs to remind him that its a lounge and that he needs to calm down. After sitting down for awhile and enjoying our drinks, we saw the manager speaking to security about us. Nobody likes being talked about from across a room.  Moments later, the same security guy that checked our ID's came back to say that the manager wanted to check one of our ID's once more. At this point we decided that our presence wasn't welcomed and we left. The only redeeming qualities were the ambience and the live band, but besides that we didn't feel we were wanted there.
author: John T.

description: Amazing view!!! Awful drinks. If a bartender can't even make a good vodka tonic, there are issues. If you go, order wine and enjoy the great views!
author: Cari T.

description: A strange sort of bar. It's a crowded mix of semi-trendy people on internet dates and country rubes who are visiting SF and staying at the hotel. The views are good, but actually not that great given high up it is. The mediocre band (I don't mean that as insult; they weren't bad, they just weren't great) was really loud. There were some interesting old-fashioned drinks on the menu that I hadn't heard of before, unfortunately it turns out they aren't popular anymore because they aren't very tasty. The bartenders were working hard and giving good service given the menu they have to work with.
author: Dolce S.

description:
Despite what you might hear, Harry's actually has a young crowd.  That is, if you go on the right night.  On Wednesday nights, 20 to 30 somethings take over the Starlight Room lending a youthful vibe an old San Francisco staple.

From waiters in tuxes to dolled up divas, you can put on your best dress and not feel the least bit over done, even in the middle of the week. Harry's takes you back to a glamorous era, before designer jeans and $100 sneakers existed. If you're the type of person who loves to dress up, but never has the right place to wear over-the-top attire, this is it! 

Dance the night away atop Union Square and see what makes the Starlight Room a true icon!
author: Lauren T.

description:
Beautiful views of Union Square and some good looking people to watch.
The live bands are always great! 
Nice central location, too.
author: Marshall M.

description:
We were rounding out our fabulous weekend in the city and wanted a nice place to grab a drink, sit, relax and enjoy the view. Well, they got the view part right, but unfortunately that was about it.
Ordered 2 slightly dirty, Ketel One martini's. We were served 2 weird smelling martini's served in champagne glasses. Presentation of a drink accounts for half the experience. In addition, the olive juice just smelled weird. We couldn't finish them.
Ordered spiced Marcona almonds. They were so strong they made my husband choke. What a waste of good Marcona almonds. Couldn't quite place the taste, but it wasn't a  pleasant one.
Wait time for service was way too long. They appeared to only have only one very nice server working the room. Too bad.
My only recommendation is to go somewhere else...
author: Maureen G.

description:
Came here on a Wednesday night (Cinco de Drinko to be exact) And it was crowded, music was bumping, drinks were reasonable, but the best thing about this place is the view! It's amazing, if you just go to take a gander at beautiful SF then you are in for a treat.
Definitely plan on going again - Wednesday nights I hear its the hot spot, and it was proven correct.
author: S. M.

description:
The Starlight Room reminds me of 38 year-old Texan women with bleached blond hair, bad make-up, a strong scent of cigarettes and cheap perfume, and a head full of memories from her glory days as a Senior when she led the cheer leading squad during the championship year.

Sure, she once succeeded and had her time in the sun-- who doesn't like a hot Texas cheerleader strutting her stuff on a winning team; the sex appeal is overwhelming-- but those times are past and so is the shiny veneer that came with it. 

Enter Harry Denton's Starlight Room at the picturesque apex of the Sir Francis Drake Hotel (note: you could copy and paste this review and it would work perfectly for the SFD Hotel).

Adorned with photos of Harry himself, arm-in-arm which C-list celebrities who once frequented his nightclub and were so desperate for attention they braved the fabulously unhip locale of Union Square and the tourists that come with it, The Starlight Room is that cheerleader: head fully of glory, facade that was oh-so-pretty 20 years ago, and a flood of tourists coming to relive her past every night of every day since then.
author: Ross S.

description:
Oh, you know. Just another normal Saturday night for me and a few of my girlfriends. What to do...? What to do...?

What else? Go to Harry Denton's Starlight Room!?!?

Well, we thought it was funny and more than anything, random. Walking through the Sir Frances Drake, I felt like a tourist. Upon walking into da lounge, we were promptly seated. Music was booming- think, fun dance wedding music. I did appreciate the band's coverage of Earth, Wind & Fire and Michael Jackson songs. Rock on! It's very dark inside and I must say, the furniture is nothing luxurious (booths and chairs were ripped, old and worn), but the view....ahhh the View!

The view of San Francisco is beautiful. You gotta go to Harry's at least once, just to see the view.

The drinks were decent- I recommend the Napa Crush. The service was okay, however, I did not appreciate how the waitress charged our friend's credit card on file for the entire table's drinks prior to showing us an itemized receipt (seriously, WTF).

It's touristy. But it's worth a visit, at least once. On a clear night.
author: Laura D.

description:
I came here with colleagues. We were in town for the night for business and Harry Denton's was recommended by the concierge at our hotel. 

When we came in the host did not give us a friendly welcome whatsoever. I was trying to ask him if an area near the bar we were interested in sitting was open for self-seating, but he basically cut me off and said he would seat us in another area. So, I had to ask him again and he finally told us that we couldn't sit there. All the while, no smile and very unwelcoming as if we were annoying him with our presence. 

We asked him if food was still being served and he said yes. 

We were seated and given one menu for three people. 

The waitress, however, was a breath of fresh air--friendly and welcoming. 

She took our drink orders while we were looked over the menu. It took us a couple minutes to figure out what we wanted because nothing especially popped out. 

Finally, we made a decision and got the waitress's attention and let her know we wanted to order food. She told us the kitchen was closed!! Of course, we were quite surprised because we had been told otherwise by the grumpy host. We asked if there was anything we could be served--bread and butter so we wouldn't be drinking on an empty stomach??? After all, the kitchen would had to have just closed in the 10 minutes or so from when we came in to when we tried to order. 

She said she would go an check and let us know. 

A while later she happened to come by our table and we had to remind her that she was supposed to be checking with the kitchen for us and she confirmed that there was nothing they could serve us and said that she would bring us the check and hurried off. 

My colleagues and I looked at each other a bit confused, because we never indicated that we wanted the check, but we were like, whatever--we're not having another round anyway. 

When guests are seated right before the kitchen closes, any good server would ask them if they wanted to put in an order before the kitchen closes. I don't know why she didn't bother asking us. 

Meanwhile, the waitress was back and forth and never brought us the check. Finally, we asked her about it and she brought it to us. I was thinking perhaps she realized the she had prematurely offered the check to us and changed her mind about bringing it--then again, she could have just forgotten about it. 

I must admit, she was overextended--she seemed to be taking care of the entire lounge until another waitress came on not long before we left. So, she had about 7 tables. 

The drink was good, so no complaints there. 

The decor was hideous. The upholstery desperately needs to be redone. It is worn and tattered. 

The crowd was a random mix. 

The DJ was great! Hip hop and top 40s. 

The view is really nice. 

Only because of the view, I would say that it isn't terrible if you just want a drink and a great view and you know what you're getting yourself into.
author: Oli A.

description:
On the 21st floor of the Sir Francis Drake Hotel, it is hard for this place not to be cool and swanky.  The interior is very pretty and has huge windows that give you an amazing view of the city. This is definitely not your "ultra lounge" or club with thumping bass and lasers, but there is a nice dance floor.  On the night I was there, they alternated between a DJ playing pop/hip-hop and a live band doing mostly cover songs.  

While my girlfriend and I did not take advantage of them, there is a large area of tables and private seating areas that would be great for a small group and give it more of that VIP feeling.  

One of the craziest aspects of this place is the huge age range of the people there, all the way from 21, up to 50s and 60s.  This is not necessarily a bad thing and makes for a more interesting and diverse crowd. 

While this is probably not a place I would want to go every week, I definitely feel like this is a great place for special occasions.  The Starlight Room is perfect for those nights where you want to go out, but you want it to be a little extra classy.
author: Ben G.

description: This place has a spectacular view of San Francisco and a great selection of wine, scotch, and beer. I would highly recommend heading here for a drink one night just for the view if not for any other reason.
author: Jay W.

description: THIS PLACE IS REALLY FUN,  the only downt thing is that the drinks at the bar are pretty expencive, but is really fun.the view is amazing. THIS IS THE TYPE OF PACE THAT A COUPLE SHOULD GO. IT WOUNT B FUN GOING SOLO.
author: Eddie L.

description: Went up on a Sat night expecting someplace to have a cocktail, look at the view and listen to the band or dance.  It was worse than any bar I have ever been in.  Packed in the entire room, 5 deep at the bar and lots of cruising older men.  This could have been a good thing for me (not) but they were interested in my daughters - twenty years their junior.  We had a laugh, got to dance and then got the heck out of there.  I could not see the decor, there were no elegant creatures to wait on us.  All in all, a waste of a great view.
author: Blythe P.

description:
This is in the 21st floor of the Sir Frances Drake Hotel.  
It's ok.  Go there for the view, not the menu, and not the sky-high priced drinks.  This menu is awful--it had waffles, and it had even chicken nuggets.  Weird and out of context with a table cloth and candle lit environment--and waitresses with long Oscar night gowns.  Mixed bag.  Food awful, no choices for someone wantng food or appetizers.  Drinks were outrageous.  We enjoyed the sunset and city lights, not the ambience of the restaurant, and NOT any of the food.  There is so much this place can do to make itself better.  I just don't get it.  I would go for the view again, WITH fine company, but never go again for any other reason.  This hotel blows it with this restaurant.  I'm surprised people ever come back.. The service was very good.  Also, unlike the bathroom shortage in the rest of this hotel, this floor for the tiny restaurant-bar had a big bathroom with mutliple stalls!  that was a rarity believe me.  This whole place is central, but it doesn't have much going for it otherwise, for the money.
author: Debbie C.

description:
Oh yea here is an update. 

Me gets screwed. Eff the details!!!
author: John F.

description: Watch out for the bartenders here. They're shady as hell. I ordered $36 worth of drinks and they "preemptively" charged me for $50 as if I was some dumbass tourist. Who does that?! ONE STAR FOR YOU.
author: Li Y.

description:
Beautiful venue, unfortunately the bouncers are complete dicks. 

Come here if you reallllly want a breath-taking view of the city. But if you want some customer service, do NOT go here. Also, the drinks are expensive and really watered-down. 

AND - the crowd is really old. 

It's really a shame since the venue is soo nice.
author: Sandy K.

description:
This place is located at the 21st floor of the hotel. It is $5 to get in. Drinks are good. Music is a little old school. The previous reviews were right about the people in the bar as being a little on the older side.
Right around 10:30 there were go-go dancers that came and were dancing on top of the tables.
author: Adriana S.

description:
The starlight room: offering SF's saddest bottle service. 

These guys try too hard to be something they're not. As with many other union square places, locals can safely pass.
author: Avi W.

description: I think their overall 3-star rating is very spot-on. It's nice...but leaves a bit to be desired. I think it's just a little too 80s glam looking right now and needs a little face lift. The views though...amazing! So pretty! Service was swell, drinks were great, great venue for a reception but didn't blow me away.
author: Chris W.

description: $15 cover charge on a Saturday night. Only 1 bar w/ a few bartenders. Small dance floor where 1/3 is taken up w/ the sound booth. Overpriced drinks but my gin/soda was made well. Live band which played fun, old-timey dancing music, but when they went on break hip-hop & R&B was piped in. "Older" crowd (no offense, just stating the facts of the evening - we'll all be there one day!) so mingling was kept to a minimum that evening for us. Glad I went post-renovation to see the "new" Starlight room but that curiosity is satisfied & I don't expect to return.
author: Marissa H.

description: Great atmosphere and views of union square and the city. Good drinks and friendly staff. Very old fashioned feel to it which was cool. I would definitely come back.
author: David D.

description:
During the winter holidays, a group of us meet up at the Starlight Room to kick off our  Xmas season revelry. We sip champagne, down oysters, and dance the night away. And yes, the city views are amazing. The space is dark and the seating is cushy. It's a very sexy setting. 

I've been to the SLR enough to say there is no one type of crowd that goes here. Oh wait, I take that back. I believe that the majority of the crowd have enough bank to afford the evening.
author: Theresa H.

description: Ok you gotta like 70s and cliche rollout stuff... but hey it was fun, tiny small dance floor but great great 8 piece band... all the old 70s stuff, Earth Wind Fire, Kool and Gang, TOP... it was great to go dance and have people there to just have fun, not cause trouble or be rude... we will go back particularly since we now like the Drake to stay for a weekend.. We're locals but playing in the City is kewl... Views were awesome!
author: Kenneth F.

description:
Okay, so, context: a friend and I were *purposely* looking for an absurd experience and were tipped off that there's a decent house show called "dresscode" here some thursday nights. Why not, eh?

I pass this place twice a day walking to and from work and have always assumed it to filled with Barry Manilow lookalikes and purple leisure suits, but it was quite hip the other night. Chartreuse and PBR combo for five bucks, plus several great house sets. It was a pleasure to finally experience the Denton.
author: Alex B.

description:
I love this place.

The servers are stunning, the views are amazing, the drinks are well-mixed, and the servers are stunning.  Took my boyo out for his big day and started here for a martini.  I LIKE what others (this means you, Jessica T) call the "random assortment of people."  It takes all kinds, as they say.

It's a fun place, inspite of the out-of-towners.  Remember: you're local.  This is your town (too).  Oh, boyo had a blast.
author: Scott W.

description: I went to a drag brunch here when a friend was in town and the food was really good and the drinks were really good but based on the price I was expecting more. 3 stars deal with it! Jk.. You should go at night and get a punch bowl of something. Especially if you're a tourist in the area.
author: Aaron H.

description:
+1 star - atmosphere  - -  just getting up to the lounge itself adds a load of 'color' to the experience.
+1 star - view
+1 star - live music
+1 star- friendly bar staff
+1 star for the bouncer  for letting me in free and giving my friend a discount on the cover charge.

-1 star - for a weird crowd - ghetto/ mixed with cougars/ mixed with sleezy old men / the whole feeling of the place is a little too 'pick-upy' for me.
-1 star for charging a cover

i'll go back, but they are not top on my list. Its a nice spot to check out if you are in union square and want to grab a drink.
author: Shadi N.

description:
Harry Denton's Starlight Room is the epitome of San Francisco class and style. It's in a historic penthouse with a Zen garden, and the staff is incredible. The clientele is varied - usually hotel guests and tourists, but there are some private soirees that rock the house sometimes. The view is awesome and the food is dependably good. My only complaint is that perhaps it's a bit too rich.  I'm gettin' old. 

I have been to the Starlight Room three times, once for a private party. I am determined to go more often, as I only live a couple of blocks from it. I had a chance to meet Mr. Denton once. It affirmed to me that this place deserves its reputation - people like Harry are the soul of this town.
author: Darren M.

description:
I always have *funny* *random* and *drunken* good times at this place. The Starlight Room transports the young and old to some other time...I can't quite place my finger on it. But the waitresses waltz around in floor length gowns with a slit up to their crotches, and the men are all dressed up in tuexdo-like outfits. It's kinda...odd. Just like the cougar woman being caressed by a younger man on the dance floor and making out as if it were their own hotel room--eew. 

But, the dance floor is a lot of fun, but bring your own group of friends or men. This place seems to draw an interesting crowd, but the music is live and pumping. Fun! 

Great views of the city!
author: Misha F.

description: Great live and dj music - a fine night out w/ a group or a date - just dance! Fun drag show Sunday brunch, too.
author: Vicki L.

description:
Summary:  Eye candy

I have had a better time at the lobby bar of the Sir Francis Drake Hotel upon which this bar sits.  The evening we went, the cover was $15 which  I suppose pays for the view.  The decor and city view are this bars strongest points.  Our waitress (hostess or whatever the PC thing to call her) was very beautiful and elegant.  Drinks are of good quality but on the expensive side.  The overall feel of the staff, though, borders on pretension.  I may be more used to the amiability of smaller (i.e. less fancy) lounges.  The DJ played a good selection of music but his beat mixing needs a bit of work.  The security personnel are quite professional.
author: Justin B.

description:
We were hanging out at Union square and had lots of things lined up for the evening. Wanted to grab a drink before that though.So hubby dear suggested Starlight. So we made a beeline and got here to celebrate with the newly wed Vik n Jen. 

Yes, the place has a spectacular view. I loved my starry night. I also loved starry night -my drink!  Looked stunning and tasted nice. The cocktails are pretty nice here.

 Only regret-I do wish they had more veggie options on the menu.
author: Natasha I.

description:
This place was fantastical! We took my cousin out for her birthday and had a wonderful time. Even though we were an hour late for our reservation, the host was still able to find us a table and seat us. The night we went there was a live band playing oldies and a DJ playing the radio hits. There was plenty of fun to be had by all!! ha ha so much fun in fact we helped ourselves to a few of the roses in the Starlight Room and security came over and told us the Flowers were for Decoration NOT Dancing! Hilarious!! Had we not watched a geriatric crew get arrested for fighting with security AND the police, we probably would have tested him for those Roses. Ha ha! 
The View here is amazing, and it really made me miss my City! The night we were there it wasn't foggy so you could see all of Union Square. I gotta get back to SF and out of Miami!
author: Kameelah R.

description:
My goodness, I don't remember the last time hubby and I danced so much and so freely - yowza!  

Some friends came out for another SF outing.  After a day of walking, drinking, chilling, listening to music, eating...we found ourselves in front of Sir Francis Drake where two of the friends were staying.  Where to go?  Too early to call it the night...friend suggested checking out the Starlight Room, why not?  Haven't been for ages and worst case will be a relaxed evening of drinks with friends.  

We got in around 8pm but no cover charge, not complaining.  We told the hostess a group of 6 and were lead to a table close to the band - there were reserved signs that she removed.  We were happy, live music with drinks sound good.  The band wasn't bad, we actually got up to dance a couple times but the DJ was even better.  After 11pm, it really kicked up with the latest pop and dance music that got everyone on the floor.  It was so packed but nothing was going to stop us.  Boy, did we sweat a storm and we paid for the body aches the day after...BUT we had so much fun!

The view is nice but go to Top of Mark if you want a view.  The layout is a bit odd but we had such a good table that it worked out well for us.  The dance floor is decent size and quite a few just hung around the large windows checking out the view and people.  We saw one girl who basically got dead drunk after a drink or two - not sure if she has low or no tolerance or a victim of foul play but she was falling over fast.  Her companion of one became three...I can only pray for her.  Girls - be warned and be careful.

We had a bottle of champagne and a mixture of drinks.  Price is as expected in a hotel, actually lower than many.
author: Gloria H.

description:
My first drag show in San Francisco I would definitely say I was impressed.  While it is a bit pricey,$45 plus 20% gratuity, the food was absolutely delicious- loved all the meat (no pun intended!).

Tell them in advance if there is a birthday- we did and I don't know if this is connected but we got front row seats.  The show apparently changes up a bit from week to week so I will most likely go again at some point.
author: Jeannie S.

description:
Love this place! Definitely a great place to go on a Wednesday night. Apparently, a lot of different groups of my friends ended up going there the same night as I for ONE REASON: 

Wednesday night is the night to go to the starlight lounge!

Loved it all. Drinks were scrumptious. Though a bit cramped, the great thing is that they have sitting areas, a gorgeous view of the city where the dance area is located, and the coat area is free! I tipped the poor girl $3 because I was allowed in and out privileges whenever I took my coat to accompany my excursions for some fresh night air.

FYI: If you want to smoke, you need to go all the way down to the street level, smoke your stuff, then make your way back up to the top.

Overall, I would come here again. Fabulous night!
author: Tisha G.

description: The Starlight Room is a San Francisco classic! Do not miss sunset, or Sunday's a Drag- brunch and show. Kenny makes the best martini in SF.
author: Bobby B.

description:
I finally got around to going to Harry Denton's Starlight room. I expected more class and elegance but, it was actually kinda sleazy. My gawd, all that bumping and grinding with perfect strangers, ok- I was the one doing all the bumping and grinding. What a great dance floor. It was sleazy in a good way.

 The view isn't as good as the one at Top of the Mark but, then again I've never shook my ass with multi-hued super models at Top of the Mark.

Overall, the Starlight Room is a lot like an older people's Ruby Skye.
Great ass shaking, good view, and beautiful people abeit an older crowd.
author: R M.

description:
I hope my friends of mine who secretly use yelp but hate yelping read this. 

Look, I went to your stupid event @ the Starlight Room and I don't understand why you, at the age of 25, think that this place is even remotely fun or exciting or in any way. 

Fair enough - I'll concede your point that the bartenders do make excellent drinks. The martinis are very tasty, which, at $10 each for whatever well pour they have, had better be good.

And, I'll freely admit that on a clear night, the view is nice - spectacular, really.

But the music is terrible. And I mean, really, really terrible. The staff is...pushy, when they don't need to be. Not as bad as Medjool but it's getting fairly close. And there's just no reason to come here for the crowd either. I understand the appeal in cougar hunting, but the hot ones aren't here, and if you're really looking for that let's just go up in the Marina and save ourselves the annoyingly stuffy elevator ride.
author: Joe K.

description:
Starlight Star bright,
A great time was had by me tonight.
I wish I may, I wish I might, 
Have the wish I wished tonight.

What was my wish?  

Basically, that when I'm 35, I won't be living in Manhattan and married to a jerk who travels to San Francisco on business and comes to the Starlight Room looking for some quick and dirty way to prove that he's still "got it."  

*Steps off soapbox and regains composure*

Anywhere that encourages this much self-reflection (ie: don't marry an a-hole) and presents an opportunity to watch tons of older males dance to Kanye West & 50 cent is a place that requires additional investigation.
author: Janney B.

description: Went there for the first time this last weekend. They had an awesome band, good drinks, nice atmosphere and friendly people. It was pretty hopping too. Maybe a little older crowd, but it's more of a mature atmosphere, if you want to get wasted and hit on chicks I suggest go to a cheap bar. I was there on a date with my boyfriend and it was great :) I'm definitely going to go back!
author: Annette D.

description:
Best drag show-brunch I've been to!  

The ladies put on a great show - they work their magic among the crowds and are amazingly easy on the eyes.  

The all-you-can eat brunch features a delicious spread of salads, deviled eggs, smoked salmon, roasted chicken breast, sausage, crisp bacon, eggs benedict, roasted potatoes, rice pilaf, French toast, roast beef, omelette station, mixed fresh fruits, assorted cakes and pastries, caramel apples + pears (yum!), fruit juices, coffee.  A great way to kick off a Sunday a top the San Francisco skyline.

"Sunday's a lovely drag!"
author: Cathy K.

description:
Came here last night to meet up  a with dear friend of mine. I meet her at 7pm (no cover charge and a great seat). As we were greeted by the nice and cute hostess we saw Harry sitting at the booth doing the books. 
We were seated at a very nice table with a awesome view. I had a champagne classic cocktail and my friend had a old fashion Margarita. Then we order a pesto pizza which was very tasty.  We were taken care of very nicely...
It was  almost 9 o'clock and notice that there were people paying $10.00 to get in....We had decided to leave. But first we had to walk around to suck in the glorious view.....
I feel its better to come to the Star Light Room at an early Happy Hour to avoid all the Yahoos.....
author: Der Maibaum L.

description:
Ooh, I've got a strange-ass collection of tiny experiences at ole' Harry Denton's that equates to the relationship drama of at least a college fuckbuddy push-and-pull.  You know, a little hee-haw for my mee-maw.

So all I remember about the day that I first wound up at the Starlight Lounge is that my friend Jessica and I did something INCREDIBLY trashy that day, 'cept I can't remember what.  Something that's the emotional equivalent to smearing the diseased diarrhea of lepers across our lips.  But for some reason we were dressed relatively appropriate to hit up some bars in SF.  We first went to the Tonga Room, but warrn't no fake tropical storm blowing through that mess at the time (we didn't hit the right half-hour), and the drinks were too much and the karaoke singer was way too far out in the square lagoon, so we left.

I think we hit up the Starlight at about 7 pm, and all the greeters were in cray-cray slingy black cocktail dresses.  This statuesque girl that I swear is the runny nosed girl from The Blair Witch Project seated us, and we ordered some kinda citrus sunset drink, a mojito, and a pizzetta.  Apparently, we had to get outta there by 8 pm, when the actual "preferred clientele" would arrive.

That's the thing -- I read the other reviews on this place, and I think everyone's going at the wrong time.  Y'all gotta go hella EARLY, so you can witness the trashy out-of-towners and listen to the amusement park funk band at a CALM pace.

We promised ourselves we'd have a kind of classy-trashy night out like that once a month.  So the next month, we saw a Craigslist ad that said Manhunt auditions were being held at the ole' Starlight.  I was in my looking-for-male-modeling-gigs-on-Craigslist phase without actually going to any calls, and of course I immediately thought, "Oh god, they ain't gonna take me.  They don't want no pock-marked, 5'10", skinny ass, hella big-toothed foo' like me on their show.  Or maybe they do!"

So we decided I would apply and I'd just go there to hella insult all the braindead fratboys applying.  Besides, I've got the cheek bones and the scary 28" waist, so maybe they WOULD take the freaky-gaunt big-mouthed look.

Then one night last year I wanted to get the hell out of my office and called up another loudmouthed friend, so we got dessert then went for drinks at the Starlight.  There was no one there but white-afro ladies with fanny packs and their husbands with transition lens gold rimmed glasses.  The singer of the band had hella Soul Glo dripping down on the hardwood stage, and Jocelyn and I got up and danced to some Supremes, Stevie Wonder, and Jackson 5, then we hightailed it outta there.

Which brings me to last night.  Don't ask me why, but for some reason I was in an elevator coming down from the Starlight Lounge with about 8 other drunken tourists trying to look like Marina guys -- except they had big ole' guts and lots of moles with their vertically striped collar shirts and hair spiking glue.  

I'm at the front of the elevator, looking down at my crotch because that's all I have room to do.

Fatty farm guy next to me in a Southern accent:  "There wuz nuthin' but a bunch of fat girls.  Just a whole bunch of muthafuckin' fat girls.  CHINESE fat girls.  Why is there so many CHINESE FAT GIRLS in that bar?"

Other guys:  "Heh heh, heh heh."

Him:  "Man, I'd fuck a CHINESE FAT GIRL.  I'd fuckin' fuck a muthafuckin' CHINESE FAT GIRL."  (Starts to gyrate and pump, and his white fabric belt is undone under his periwinkle XXL butterfly collar dress shirt.)  "I'd (pump) FUCK (pump pump) a CHINESE (bump) FAT GIRL."

Of course I'm a split second too late in turning to him with my stone cold eyes and saying, "I'm a Chinese fat girl.  Are you going to fuck me, mutha fucka?"
author: Haaay East Bay l.

description: Overall we were disappointed with our experience. Our waitress was rude at first and forgot to place our food order. After about 20 mins, we got our punch bowl drink, which was fun! Then about 45 mins after we sat down and our order of Mac and cheese and chicken nuggets still were not here, we requested our check. Needless to say, I would not recommend this place besides the view and punch bowl bur defiantly don't order food.
author: Melanie M.

description:
What a scene!  Every time I turned my head, I had a new, weird site to see.  There was the wannabe Milli Vanilli/Rick James dude rocking the keyboard for the live band.  Then there's the too old to be going out on a Saturday night couple grinding and sucking face on the dance floor.  Sitting down, we have the middle-aged Russian men with the peroxide blonde hookers trying to earn a quick buck.  Aside from all the interesting "scenery," I have had fun dancing here, as they have a pretty good mix of music.  And the drinks are pretty tasty as well.  The set-up is what I would imagine and old school Brat pack type lounge would be like.

So, come to this place ready for some entertainment.  It's the perfect mix of cheesy and classy.
author: Danielle B.

description:
Go to Starlight room on a quiet night with only a few people.  Don't go to get down and dirty; the views and ambiance are best appreciated in a romantic way; sipping martini's while flirting and looking over the city.

The Wednesday night party is really bridge and tunnel.  Not really a big fan.

I am a fan, however, of Mr. Harry Denton himself.  I had the pleasure of meeting him this past Wed at the weekly Wed night party's 12 year anniversary celebration and it was a real treat to meet such an iconic San Franciscan.  Did you know that the signature Christian Louboutin red sole originated with red nail polish painted on the bottom of the very first pair created?Yea, neither did I until Harry shared this tidbit with me.

But really- that red lipstick they make the waitresses wear is so dated and tacky.
author: Genevieve M.

description: I can definitely see how someone would think that this place is a touch on the cheesy side, but there's something about it that I like. The views are amazing -- clearly the selling point here -- and the drinks and service are good. I really (really!) like how they lay out their menu, decade by decade, with drinks to match. It's a fun concept and the drinks that I've tried are definitely well executed. The overall vibe is kind of old school San Francisco with a little tourism factor, but there is live music in the evenings (at least on the weekends) which I find pretty fun! In terms of VIEWS,  I would take the Top of the Mark over Harry Denton's, but I think both provide pretty views for people visiting the city.
author: Shannon E.

description:
Very cool view. 
You can go with Dressed up or casual..
But it is pretty looking view so You might want to dress up for a bit to spice up with the view they got. 
Definitely for View spot.
author: Yumiko F.

description: Snobby staff!!!  great views, if you can look past the DIRTY DIRTY windows that have probably not been cleaned for years!  Staff is rude, and crowd is weird!  Skip this place and save your wallet a cover and expensive (weak) drinks!
author: D C.

description:
The place may look shabby, but once you get over the décor you may just enjoy yourself. There's always a different crowd so it varies. (Hit or miss) They have a killer view of Union Square on a clear night, and the staff is decent and accommodating at times.  I was here a couple of weekends ago for my bday and had a blast. Although the dance floor is teeny, we were able to shake a little something with everyone else. 

As a side note, I was given some crazy cocktail with an odd flavor (Coconut Infused Vodka?) with pineapple juice, shouldn't have indulged for I was sick the next day. We coined it the "Roofie drink" ;)
author: deitra T.

description:
People that don't like the Starlight Room are people that have NO SOULS.

Okay, damn. I'm an atheist. But, still. This place is beyond awesome. I don't really know how to describe it...Just imagine a handfull of slightly confused Japanese tourists standing in one corner, a group of rowdy Germans doing the 'naughty dance' by the window, and on the dance floor a throbbing mass of young, wanna-be yuppies gyrating to some of the most horribly preformed music you will ever hear in your life.

It's like watching four trains collide at once. Sure, it kinda makes you sick but then again...you feel energized by it.

Great views, good drinks (crazy expensive, though). But you can really never go wrong with CHEESE. And this place really delivers.
author: Pamela D.

description:
If you want to be picked up by foreign men and older doctors from out of town, this is the place for you!!

Seriously....this place is a pick up joint.  But it's a classic, so you go when you have out of town guests...the view alone is worth it.

Wednesday nights are mad, Thursdays are a bit more tame.  Lots of space, good size dance floor, and decent drinks.  Also good for my friend who was driving and wanted non-alcoholic beer!  They delivered, PLUS it was German which he appreciated (being German! :-P)

So overall, 3.5 stars...I won't go back on a regular basis, but it's fun every so often.  Best get there before 10 pm to avoid the $10 cover.
author: Melanie N.

description: What a great time we had last Sunday at the Sunday's A Drag show in the Starlight Room at the Sir Francis Drake Hotel. The brunch buffet was well stocked and good quality and the drinks were well prepared. The fun drag  show was hosted by the very entertaining and very talented Donna Sachet. Ms. Sachet sings all her own songs (no lip syncing for her!) This is a perfect destination for locals and for visitors who what to have a bit of the San Francisco Drag Queen experience.
author: Lucinda L.

description:
Harry Denton's Starlight Room is a B-Star Lost with a physically painfully soundtrack.

It's industry party time, and my big account rents out Harry Denton's to get a serious drink on. (Thank you for the free drinks and hilariously "...unique" experience!)

Let's start with the most offensive first, so the rest of the complaints don't sound so bad... My god, the music -- 80's hip hop and funk alternatingly played by a DJ and a cover band -- is *SO* bad, you wished they played it louder. That way, you'd go deaf and not have to prolong the pain.

Thinking about the crowd at Harry Denton's, I've finally figured it out. It's not bridge and tunnel. It's Lost. It's an an island populated by random freaks. There's the table from Big Hair, Idaho, clad in USDA Prime sized blue jeans. Next to them, a table of players who were cool 30 years ago. They're far too old to interest the table of 400-year old Chinese eggs, searching for fountains of youths to suck dry. The only youth inside is the vapid wait staff. Add to this very special episode my large party of smarmy technogeek all-stars, hell-bent on partying medium. Everyone hangs back in their lounge chairs, waiting to see what freaky thing the island will do next.

Our waitress either has just gotten dumped by her sugar daddy, or gets off on the idea that she serves abuse, not booze -- the girl's in a stinky pissy mood. Getting drinks from her is like trying to squeeze bloody mary's from a stone. Thankfully there's catered food, and it's actually not bad.

The cuts of roast beef are delish. The crab cakes are  surprisingly good -- spicy, with lots of real crab meat, crispy and not too greasy. The only bad appetizer is the not-so-fresh foie gras. Tonight's star of the Starlight Room: bacon-wrapped prawns. Ultimately, wrapped in bacon almost forgives anything.

It's a good thing the food and drinks were flowing freely, or I would have gone all Lord of the Flies on the island and started sacrificing people Piggy style -- starting with the Worst DJ Evar. 

Don't go. The view isn't all that -- dirty windows half-obstructed by neighboring buildings. On a weeknight, there's no cover, but you would do better off skipping out on this live-action Lost and curling up with a slightly rancid tub of butter. You get the same heavy, overwhelming sensation, but you can puke from disgust in the courtesy of your own home.
author: Perci N.

description: This place is definitely a tourist destination with great views. The ambiance is interesting. I felt like I was walking into a swanky bar from the 60s. The drinks are good, but a little pricey. They have a $5 cover after a certain time in the evening. The music they played the night I was there was mainstream. It was fun watching the 40-50yr olds dance to it, they were pretty good lol.
author: Danielle R.

description:
So you have friends from out of town and you want to show them a true SF venue with brunch- well Harry Denton's Sunday Brunch can be one of your choices...
I have to say the food wasnt that great- Breakfast choices of sausage links, bacon and ham, scrambled eggs and a carving table and a few other hot entrees...A bread and dessert table...nothing extraordinary- BUT what they lack in food they certainly gain back with the entertainment headed by Donna Sachet and her amazing co-performers...My favorites were Cassandra Cass and Wynona Juggs...their adage of " The more you drink- the BETTER I'll look" does not apply here!  Brava gurls :-)
author: Arissa C.

description:
Come here on a Wednesday night where the crowd is younger.  Come after dinner before 10pm to avoid lines.  If you're of the female persuasion, there's a chance there is no cover.

The first time I walked in here, I was intimidated by the place and the prices, I didn't know what to order.  So I went with a standard cosmo.  I tasted it - not too much alcohol, not too sweet - PERFECTION.  So good, I was sucking them down one after the other.

Usually when I come in, I grab a drink then head over the dance floor where the view is.  The view is alright but I love that I can see outside.  And their windows really should be cleaned more often.  Inevitably, some old guy is getting down on the dance floor which is always a source of amusement, as long as there's only one of them, and no more than one.

Music is pretty good.  Top 40 dance music.  The first time we tried to request a song, the DJ's security guy (they have those?) said they didn't do requests.  But if two cute girls approach you, are you really gonna deny them?  So DJ took our request and we danced the night away to Chris Brown's "Forever."

Highlight of our first time: Sean Penn was there.

Highlight of our second night: Our friend snagged an open table and a bottom of Dom.

Call me a snob but I like bougy loungey places.  And I prefer a cocktail over a beer any day.  But minus 2 stars because theyre so absurdly expensive and because they don't clean their windows for a place with a view.  And for a place described as "elegant", the gogo dancers don't really seem to belong.  Or know how to dance.
author: Seechung L.

description:
We went to the Sunday brunch show for a friend's birthday.  The food was classic hotel buffet food (the eggs were a little under done) but screw the food, bring on the drag show.

I have to say this is a GREAT drag show!  Amazing lip sync, beautiful bodies that any woman would kill for, hilarious outfits and song selection, extremely fun, and the MC has the most beautiful voice when she sings.  Yes, they are men in drag lip syncing to songs...but you let yourself go along for the ride and they are amazing performers belting their songs out just for you.

Having been to drag shows in NYC, London, Spain, and now SF...this is the best I've seen.  Seriously...they are gorgeous and talented.  As a confident straight man I gotta tell you, I'd buy any of these ladies a drink and see where it goes.
author: Ryan G.

description:
Al right then, so if you show up in a pair of nice dressy sneakers that are the newest thing  you still couldn't get a good vibe going in to the starlight room.
then if you are not really in the mood for paying 25 dollars for two(2)6oz alcoholic beverages  while being looked at from head to toe because you & your date are the only ones  dressed like it's 2006 ad and not 1995 also if you are under thirty don't even bother stopping in because you might run into one of your parents friends dancing to erotic city with another one of your parents friends and while  both are drunk lip syncing to the tune. so be forewarned it's not where you want to go on a Wednesday night even if they are playing tweak techno at Minna.
sssssssso,the starlight room could be a bad ass joint for a lot more people to enjoy and still promote classy.they just need to get caught up with the 2000s.
author: DJ B.

description: I like this place because of the great views and the energy. Everyones dressed to impress and alot of regulars are committed to the place.  I used to go here alot (in my single days) and the majority of the men here were good looking and *ahem* my type....wear suits and buy girls drinks. Call that a fetish but I always had a great time there. Gets crowded on the dancefloor so be prepared to butt elbows with other people.
author: Katie Anne N.

description:
Go, go, and go!  How fun!  Went to their 12:00 brunch/drag show with performers Donna, Alexis, Cassandra and Lady Tia.  They were terrific!  The host (and performer), I think it was Donna, was witty, engaging and had great vocals.  The songs were eclectic, the costumes glittery and exciting, and the acts just superb!

Another awesome thing.  It's on the 21st floor of the Sir Francis Drake Hotel.  Beautiful view!

The food -  The brunch is buffet style and in the rear of the floor with a sweet site of the city.  Don't miss out on the french toast!  My friend asked and someone told her that creme brule was mixed into the batter.  (I thought it was crack!).  Anyways, it was DEE-licious!  So was the devil's egg, the chocolate covered strawberry and pretty much every other pastry layed out on the table.  

Yes the 40 bucks is a little pricey for brunch (esp. when compared to places like St. Francis where you can fill your belly for less than $15), BUT you can eat AS MUCH as you want, the food IS delectable and the experience is just pure entertainment!
author: Swetha G.

description:
Sunday's a Drag, at least for brunch at Harry Denton's Starlight room.   There is a drag show, yes, but let me talk about the brunch, first.

I'm sure we've all had buffet food from a chafing dish~  that's what you get to eat.   Many of the dishes were empty, since it took a while to replenish them and some things just shouldn't be sittin' above a Sterno.  Case in point:  Eggs Benedict.  My booth-mate commented, 
 
'Oh, you're so good, you're not eating the English muffin' but I had to reply that I was unable to cut through it with my knife.  It was that hard.

The show was fun.  The emcee was quite raunchy and changed her outfits between each act.  The queens who did the musical performances were OK, but sometimes appeared to be mad at the world with all their thrashing about.  Not cute.

Go for the cocktails and the experience;  I'd have to give just half a star for the food.
author: Karen W.

description:
We went to the Starlight Room for their drag brunch. It was fun!

The food was good; lots of variety and good quality. Make sure you show up a little early; we got there right before the show, and barely had time to fill our plates before the entertainment started.

I think I saw my first drag show in the early 80's. I've been to a lot of them. The performers for this show were excellent. The hostess had an elegant Olympia Dukakis thing going and sang her own numbers. I really enjoyed her. The performers were gorgeous and really interacted a lot with the crowd. 

It was a tourist's drag show, though; pretty clean and not particularly campy. I'm rather fond of amateur, chubby older drag queens with a little chest hair peeking out and a great sense of humor. This was definitely not that kind of drag show. These gals were just gorgeous.

Our server was a lovely little thing; she was very welcoming and attentive. 

We had a really nice time. We just about fell over when we got the bill; this is not an inexpensive brunch! We had such a good time, though, we didn't mind the expense.

If you have friends in town, particularly straight friends who want to do something that's a little outrageous and fun, this brunch is a good place to take them.
author: Artemis E.

description: This place used to be nice, I don't know what happened!! The Starlight Room used to be an upscale club with good music and a great atmosphere. Now it is a total DUMP!!! The music was bad, the place was filthy and don't even get me started on the 'jersey shore" crowd!! Don't waste your time or money at this place, there are far better clubs to frequent in SF.
author: Catherine M.

description:
I love watching old people rub up on each other on the dance floor! Classic environment where the older gentlemen on business trips slip their wedding rings into their pockets. No, keep your hotel number to yourself, and your ear hair is talking to me. 

Cute lounge areas with lovely views though...so if you really want to come here, do it first thing before any dancing activities. Try midweek for less sweaty bodies blocking the skyline. Heavy out-of-towners on the weekend. Extreme age variances.
author: Tanya P.

description:
I've only attended the Sunday drag show, and it was definitely a delight. 

Tickets were easy to reserve, even at last minute. We took Bart since driving through the city can be such a hassle, and it was only a few blocks from the Powell station.

The service was prompt, and drinks were reasonably priced (I recommend ordering a Bellini). The food was served brunch style, and the presentation was pleasing. The array of breakfast items were tasty, but most importantly, so were the desserts.

The one hour drag show was so much fun. Each performer had a wonderful style of their own, and "Whole Lotta Times" was worth every dollar. The hostess "Donna Sachet" was entertaining, especially the star of the show "Cassandra Cass". If you bring guests, keep in mind Cass's performance could be considered a tad risque.

If you are looking for a unique Sunday outing, this is the place!
author: Elizabeth G.

description:
Welcome to the United Nations of Clubbing.

Wait... it's more than that.  Where else are you going to be able to dance between a guy who just turned 21 sometime this past week and the leader of AARP?  I mean, there was a guy who almost needed a walker to move around .... and around him were people who could be his great grandchildren as well.

This is a really nice establishment located on the top floor of the Sir Francis Drake Hotel.  Views all around, and great setup for socializing as well as a rather smallish dancefloor at one end of the club for dancing fools.  The bar is on the opposite end, and has quite a line on their usually packed Wednesdays, called "Indulgence".  

Just standing in line, I knew this would be a bizarre night.  What a mixed bag of patrons, but it is supposed to be the "thing to do" on Wednesday nights in SF, and apparently, all age groups are privy to this fact.  The line was very slow-moving, though - as they loaded  a single elevator to capacity and waited for the next one to come back, etc.  I almost left because based on what I was  seeing, this was not going to be my scene, but then the guy in front of us gave us VIP tickets.  OK, so no cover - - I guess a new place is worth checking out if we won't have to pay to get in.

On your walk to the restroom or to the bar, a girl anywhere under 40 is likely to get hit on at least 10 times  - - each way.   Harmless, but it does make you want to roll your eyes.  "You could be my father, buddy.  Stop staring."  If you are above 40 yourself, or like older men - this might be the venue of your choice.  I have nothing against older folks - I just tend to expect more composed behavior from them, that's all.

The bartenders were really nice - but definitely something was amiss. Apparently, when I go to the bar to buy drinks, they whip out the big, tall glasses to fill my order, and each drink is about half the price with one thrown in for free.  When my guy friends bought drinks, they used the small glasses and I kid you not - charged double.  I guess it pays to be a girl, but still!

The music was all over the place.  In a good way, one can say that there was a little something for everyone from age 15 to 65.  I didn't mind the contrast so much - but for someone lookin for JUST hip hop, or JUST 80's, or JUST one kind of anything -  Starlight Room is not for you.  There was one man, perhaps in his late 40's, who was breakdancing to an oldie, slippin' and slidin' to hip hop, doing the wave on his own (you could tell he'd worked hard on it, too, in front of his mirror at home) and sometimes danced like he was having some sort of seizure.  Good, he was not.  Entertaining -  definitely.

There's a pretty good time to be had here if you go with good friends and just want to mingle and meet new people, and don't much care what kind of new people you meet.  I think it'd be interesting, at least.  

Seating is a bit weird - - plenty of booths and table/chairs to sit at, except all are empty and not occupied, but have a "RESERVED" sign placed on the table, preventing you from using it.  Some remained reserved and unoccupied through the whole night, so I don't quite understand the concept.

I give it 3-stars because the club's look and layout is nice - and drinks are good - but this is definitely not an elite party club, or it's most definitely not the hippest place to be in your 20s or 30s.  In my 40's I think I would enjoy this place a lot more, and will return then to change my rating as I see fit.

Until then - -- if you want to be around a lot of people on a particular Wednesday night - head to Starlight Room.  That, you will get.  If it's a weekend night, there are lots of better clubs out there with better music, dancing, and crowds.  

Would I go again?
Um.... I wouldn't be totally against going, but I would try to make a case for doing something else.

Their brunch, however, is enticing.  I would not mind trying out their Sunday brunch to see how that works for me.  I do love breakfast!
author: Grace K.

description:
Why does everyone give it such a bad rating?  What do you expect?  I mean, this isn't a place to take all of your friends for the evening, but, shoot, if you're in from out of town, or you need a quick drink with a killer view and a little schwank action, why the heck not go to Harry Denton's.

I mean, I hear you don't like the crowd and all, there's definitely some truth to that, but you can BE YOUR OWN CROWD.  It's just a little more difficult that way.  Crowd isn't everything, nor is historical precedence.

Harry's alright with me.
author: Abendigo R.

description: Awesome view, cool place overall, but a bit ont he expensive side - even for SF.  I always meet fun people when here so I am a fan.  Last time we went coat check was free & met lots of people claiming to be models (part time I'm sure) but regardless led to a nice ambiance.
author: George M.

description:
Indeed it is a trip.
My Friday night here was so fun. It is a very interesting and mixed crowd. I felt so grown up being there (that's a good thing).

I think it's soo cute that older couples come here and dance dance dance, (way to keep that spark alive!!) the crowd also included cougars, a gay couple, a foreign couple and lots of other random groups and couples... I LOVE to people watch and this was a very fun place to do it.

MEANWHILE the BF and I also worked on keeping our own spark alive here, its nice to be able to dress up and go somewhere fancy once in a while. The drinks were OK, the band was good and the DJ was also pretty kick ass. 
If I was a local I probably wouldn't be a regular but I'm very glad to have had this experience.
author: Claudia G.

description:
I walked in here with a bag stuffed with a 30 gb iPod, a bottle of Cusano Rojo Mezcal and a bottle of 12 year Glenlivet- items I had won at my employee party.  Nothing could kill my high.  

There I was in the Harry Denton Starlight Room, owned by Kimpton group, with my girlfriend and a group of drunk mexicans, and Jon, whose jewish.  We showed up at about one thirty five and ordered a woodford reserve manhattan and a glass of Nicolas Feuilatte Rose Champagne, which costs us somewhere near forty dollars.  The bartender was nice,  italian, and our drinks were superb.

Then the lights went on.  Then some ass came around and told us that we had to finish our drinks.  Legally, we thought, we could stay until two o'clock right?  I didn't go to Hastings, but I thought that was pretty much correct.  I said, "How about five minutes."  He replied, "I'll give you one minute."  Then he came back very soon.  I don't know if it was a minute, I was kinda drunk on the red worm.  He told us we had to finish our drinks.  I said something to the lines of harassment and my gal gave him the uptown attitude and talked about bar time.

Then this goober actually took our drinks out of our hands.  On buddha's belly, I swear to god it was only one fifty.  Our drinks were still full.  Sacrilege!  CarrieAnn was pissed and asked for his name, and the gent spelled it out for us loudly and insultingly, like he knew he wasn't going to get in trouble.  She told him mockingly that he was very good at his job, in which he replied, "For your information, I'm a mortgage broker!"  wtf?

"So you must be making millions!"  She said.  I replied, "For your information-,"   And then I said something kinda bad.  He got right up in my face and replied.  "You know, little boy, if we were out on the street I would give you a full body massage."  

So I headed into the elevator and I was actually excited.  I never get to swear at anyone.  What a jerk!  Baby was livid.  We went to the front desk of the Francis Drake and asked to speak to a manager, followed by this drunk french guy who was behind us being french saying, "fehqing sheeet, dat guy wez sech ah ezhol!"

We got an escort back upstairs.  I think I even did a little jig in front of my coworkers who were chilling in the lounge.

The manager was in his stree clothes and all the bartenders had taken off their tuxeo jackets.  One dress shirt was even de-sleeved.  I thought that classy.  Two little girls were sitting in a booth with glasses of over oaked California red thinking, "Oh my gawd, why are they, like, interrupting our after party?"

The manager reimbursed us with money from his own wallet.  Doorass was gone.  We went home and baby wrote three different high ups within the specific hotel, restaurant and bar faction we were insulted in about our unpleasant experience.  They failed to resolve the issue appropriately and we weren't invited back.  We thought about going last night.  I kinda want to go and drop a multi hundred on a nice varietal champagne and a couple glasses of Louis, and then test their bar time quota.

Four stars for the italian bartender.  Negative twenty seven stars for the doorman and one star for Harry Denton's Starlight room.
author: Ashby U.

description:
Wowwowwheee!! My bachelorette night got started at the Starlight Room. Yeah! One dozen ladies - comin right up. We all felt very sex in the cityesque with our sexy outfits and frouffy drinks to match :o).  We had to make sure everyone around us knew it was my bachelorette party, so my friends crowned me with a pretty little tiara and a sash that read, Sexy Little Thing. That's me. Uh huh. Anyhoo - service was excellent - they paid me lots of attention! 

The best part of all - one of the owners was having a drink up there and he noticed our party full of crazy gals - he offered to foot the bill. Rock on Mr. Part Owner - You deserve a lapdance! I'll be back to find you and give it to you ;-)

Oh what a night!....Then off we went to The Mint... where bitches got even crazier....
author: Aim E.

description:
Absolutely BEAUTIFUL view!! 
Small dance floor, ok music... 
Pricey drinks but you are paying for the view, and I think most nights its only about $10 to get in, compared to $20 or $30 at other clubs in SF. 
I think its absolutely worth it if you want somewhere more high end and less ghetto.
author: Tori E.

description: Walked into this place with three other friends at around 12:00 a.m. on Saturday, March 8.  We went because I've been here before twice and it has always been hilarious (good people watching, fun music, etc). Bouncer asked for our IDs. As we were getting them out, we asked if there was a cover.  He looked over at the girl behind the desk, and asked "is there a cover?"  She looked at us, looked down at her book or whatever, then said yes, $20.  No smile from anyone, no nothing.  Wow - so this bouncer didn't know there was a cover, and the cover appears to be subjective.  I've been here before, twice, and the cover was $10.  Bottom line: shady business, and it's not that great to begin with to warrant $20.
author: Ashley R.

description:
I recently visited this establishment while on my first trip to the city. I had made reservations two weeks in advance because it has an amazing view (located on the 21st floor, right next to Union Square). I made them for 8pm because we weren't planning on staying long, and we figured we would get in and out . 

When the three of us arrived we had to stand next to the elevators because we were 10 minutes early for our reservations. As more customers entered they also stood in the tight area with us, constantly moving as the elevator doors opened. Despite the fact that we were the first ones to arrive and the fact that we had reservations, we somehow were pushed to the back as others entered . None the less, we got to the rude host. 

An out of town visitor that was looking for a great view of the city, I was also unaware that this was more of a bar than a restaurant. Unfortunately one of the girls with us ( I say girl because we are 24 and the rest of the crowd were men and women 50 and older, mind you on a Saturday night) left her ID in the car. The man at the front was angry because I was unaware that we needed to prove we were 21 to get in. We offered to get the ID and come back, but after insulting us and the fact the we were from Southern California, he told us that we could still enter. For some reason he didn't feel the need to check the IDs of the two of us that had them. She should have had her ID, and we take full responsibility for that, hence the fact that we told him that we would go and get it.

Shocked that he was so demeaning, we proceeded into the bar to be greeted once again with a name request. After giving my name, they seemed to have a problem locating my reservation (even though I had received a call the previous day confirming that reservation). What a shock for the man that there were two pages of reservations! Seemed a little strange that he couldn't figure that out, but he finally found us.

On to our seats.  We sat, placed an order for drinks and appetizers (of course the friend without the ID ordered water) and were disturbed that the man at the door wouldn't stop staring at us. After our orders were delivered service was nonexistent from that point on. I waited about 10 minutes to get a fork so that I could eat, and we had to ask our waitress if we could have our empty waters refilled (it was strange that we had to say "excuse me "serveral times as she walked by before she actually looked our way, even though onme of the waitresses actually bumped my foot while passing our tabe because the area was so tight).

After we had finished we were definitely ready to leave. When the waitress approached our table, my friends explained how we felt neglected because of the way that we were treated at the door, in addition to being ignored because of what we could see, was probably our age. She didn't seem to care, and we later found out, that she told the man at the door what we had said.

As we were signing our checks, the man from the door approached us and told us that we needed to leave as soon as we were finished signing our checks. Then he escorted us to the door where he opened the elevators for us so that he could get us out faster.

Obviously unhappy with the way that we were treated, we described our incident to an attendant downstairs who called the manager down for us. The manager also wasn't too concerned  about our story and accused us of having fake IDs (despite the fact that the man upstairs didn't even look at them), and then said that we had given our side of the story but he would check with his staff. He had no intentions of taking us seriously. We got his manager's name, and that manager's name as well. Don't think it will make any difference though. 

So basically, as we felt, we were discriminated against because we were young and it was assumed that we didn't have money to be there or tip well. Coincidently, we were talking about our experience in a parking garage and a woman overheard us and asked if we had just been at the Starlight Room! We couldn't believe that she knew where we had just been! She explained that she had worked there and that it was regular policy to treat younger customers disrespectfully. Apparently the staff equates youth to poor and unimportant. 

It's really unfortunate that this experience took place because the hotel (Sir Francis Drake) and the Starlight Room was amazingly beautiful. It has a breathtaking view and classiness reminiscent of the 1930s. I only gave one star because of the view and the decor, and also because I had to in order to submit my review. My first trip to San Francisco was ruined because of the appalling behavior of the staff of the Starlight Room.
author: Leeann M.

description: This is pretty old school place. Definitely not my scene but can see why it has been a Wednesday night staple. This is a hotel lounge that sits on top of the Sir Francis Drake hotel so the view of the city is quite fly. There are a bunch of lounge tables throughout the room with a main bar as you walk in. There are other makeshift bars and a small dance floor towards the back. Crowd is interesting and seems more like tourists. Can be a romantic experience if you're a little bit older in age.
author: Ed L.

description:
The Starlight Room...where the champagne flows free and the cougars run wild!

I must admit, I've only been here a hand full of times for some invite only parties but it was cool. It definitely had that Old Time San Francisco vibe to it. You just know that place has some history...if only the walls could talk.
author: Don C.

description:
Okay, I know that natural daylight is the nemesis of the drag queen, but for God's sake, if people pay $45 pp for brunch at the Starlight Room, they are expecting a city view!!!! The closed curtains were a huge disappointment. The brunch was also a bit of a letdown. I'm not saying it wasn't good. It had all the standards, prime rib, eggs benedict, omelet bar..., but nothing really WOW-ed me about the food.
I'm still going to dole out 4 stars though, because "Sunday's a Drag" is an absolute kick. I was worried the show might be a bit redundant since I'd been to the famous Finnochio's prior to their close, but the show was fresh, funny, and damn, I'm still very puzzled that the Madonna impersonator could have possibly been born a boy. I don't want to give away too much about the show, but get ready to laugh harder than you have in years and beware that you might end up with a face-full of boobies (I did twice).
author: Michelle D.

description: Great experience! We came here from out of town. Doorman was very friendly and once inside we were seated right away by a lovely gentleman. Service was fast and friendly. Drinks were strong but reasonably priced. Music was good with plenty of room to dance. Classy place without the "Hollywood" ego
author: Deb B.

description:
The music here on Wednesday was mainstream hip-hop for a lot of the time, so that's good for some people.

Here's a little tip which I think most of the Yelp audience won't need:
If you, as Chris Rock would say, are the old guy in da club, rocking your 5 PM blazer and business shirt won't help. When you walk into a club and no one else is wearing a blazer, don't despair, even though your hair is starting to fall out. You could at least try taking off your blazer. Then you won't look as old. It only takes a second. And don't be a sketchy guy or run into people on the dance floor. This isn't the trading floor.

Oh, and if you live in, like Vallejo or San Jose, why do you bother driving so far just for a Wedneday night? Do you have a job?

Here's one other tip: If you meet someone, and you notice something unusual about them, like maybe their race or hair color or height or profession, don't say, "Hey, I have a ____ fetish." It's not a turn-on. I haven't been, but I hear lines like that may be okay at the Power Exchange. Maybe save the line for there? Thanks.

But the view at Starlight is really nice.
author: Ellie P.

description:
I would never think to come here on my own.. but on my company's dime.. i'm never one to turn down free food and drinks.

Friday night, my company rented the starlight room for happy hour and we ate food, danced, and shook up the joint.  The view from the place is spectacular.  It's breath taking to experience the sunset from this spot.  The company was great, the staff was attentive and they were very decent to us--a little snobby, but I was having too much of a good time to get down about it.  The DJ rocked!  Played top 40 and JT (my favorite) and everyone was happy.

9:30 rolls around and they open the place to the general public.  As I'm looking at the crowd, I'm thinking "this place is soooo seedy!!"  The starlight room is like where all these stinking rich men come with high class "escorts".  It's secluded from the rest of the city and very dim and intimate.  The tables are designed for quiet chatting--they are no more than 2 feet in diameter!  No one looks at anyone else and they mind their own business.

Anyway, in a nutshell--I wouldn't come back, but it was definitely cool to see the famous "starlight room" once in my life.  

It has such an old world feel... I wonder what it was like in its heyday.

p.s. i hear that if you are the mid- to late-twentys crowd.. wednesday night at the starlight room has a great party... the fridays - sundays are the awkward nights.
author: Steph M.

description: One of the best places in the city for a fantastic view. Right on Union Square, this lounge/bar/nightclub on the 21st floor is reasonable priced (10$ entry charge on a Friday night) and averagely priced drinks - which could be a little stronger -  is a perfect place for catching some drinks on a clear night or dancing. That night, the music started off with some jazz and country (from a live band) and then went on to play the usual Top 40 hiphop/RnB numbers. The crowd is mostly 30+, but great hangout nevertheless!
author: Priyanka S.

description: This building is amazing and on the 21st floor, with amazing views! I came here on a Sunday for brunch and a drag show. It was fantastic! Pretty swanky but also very touristy. I highly recommend this to visitors, the view alone is worth it!
author: Thomas Nathan S.

description: We went to the Starlight room on March 8th. There was a special put on by Frenchy le Freak.  The music was awful. All House music, loud and obnoxious.  I have been to Harrys many times and there is often the same problem.  Many people eager and willing to dance.  No good dance music.  Try and ask the DJ or the management to play danceable music and they blow you off. In the meantime, patrons stand around waiting for a decent song. After 30 minutes most people leave in disgust after paying their $20 cover charge.  This place puts on like they care about their patrons, but they simply don't.  They have their own agenda.
author: Steven H.

description: Crowded late in the evening, but fun for dancing and curling up at a table. Some great drinks and an enjoyable place to be. Little bit of an older crowd and sometime hard to find a table, but an interesting place.
author: Patrick B.

description:
Sunday's A Drag is now 5 years old, which is a long run for any performance production in this always percolating entertainment mecca called San Francisco.  When you take two of the most respected, vital, dedicated local legends with a great idea and let them do their thing, you sometimes get the Gold Ring, and Donna Sachet along with Harry Denton have done that with this sassy, classy brunch show in one of the most magnificent top floor Hotel showrooms with a view, in the charming Sir Francis Drake Hotel that graces the urbane top end retail scene surrounding Union Square.  

My partner and I decided on the Noon show, made a reservation and arrived at 11:30.  We were greeted by a young stud turned out in a tuxedo with contemporary flair who seated us in a beautiful red booth where we had a great view of the bar. the stage and quick access to the lavish buffet and fresh cooking stations which offered an abundant, gorgeous array of fresh fruits, juices, pastries, bagels, french toast, bacon, sausage, vegetables and potatoes, plus the cook to order omelet station and carving station that served up the slice of prime rib you ask for.  With all this came fixings of every possible size, shape, taste and preference, talk about abundant and lavish and those words capture the bounty and impeccable quality of this brunch.

At Noon the first show started with a terrific light show of spots and colors along with some great, upbeat music.  Donna Sachet, the first lady of San Francisco, entered the showroom singing and took immediate and loving command of a show that had us crying from laughing and applauding wildly for some of the best classic drag I've ever seen.  Donna doesn't lip sync which is almost never the case in any drag show, and she is GOOD!  The songs she selected were just perfect and her sharp, spontaneous humor made the show fly by almost too quickly.  There were three additional performers at this particular show and each was sensational and a show stopper in her own right.  Holotta Tymes is sensational, a show stopper in her own right with a number combining Lady Gaga and Baby Jane in the infamous telephone routine, and then a hilarious and sexy Mae West type song.  She's really a terrific actress and knows her craft well.  Also in the cast was Cassandra Cass, also a towering inferno of talent and a television star to boot.  Rounding out the the cast was Lady Tia, another star in her own right.

The show is supposedly based on the Looonnnnngggggg running shows at Finocchio's which was the most legendary drag show in America for at least a half a century.  But this is a different type of event, and as fun as any live show in San Francisco, loaded with talent thanks to the Grand Dame of this City Donna Sachet and the amazing Mr. San Francisco, Harry Denton.  This is an only in San Francisco event that I hope runs forever, and you get an excellent brunch, great cocktails and champers, fabulous service and a great mix of folks from all over the world.  This is a MUST SEE!
author: Stu S.

description: The decor is romantic, with gorgeous chandeliers and beautiful drapes.  It really has a 70's disco look.  Menu selection is slim, offering only tiny plates, and no meat selections if you're a carnivore.  Pizzas are the size of a small serving dish.  Five pieces of shrimp if you want seafood, and all these plates are $15-20 each.  The dessert chocolate mousse was delicious though.  Definitely have dinner beforehand.  Drinks are overly-priced as well.  For two people, you're bound to spend over $100 just sipping cocktails, plus additional cover charge for an evening of live band and DJ.  The crowd is mid-twenties to over 50's.  The atmosphere and people here are fabulous!  We'd visit here again, but not on a weekly basis.  I still have to check out 'Sunday's a Drag' brunch for a different kind of entertainment.
author: Christine R.

description:
I have been here twice.  Once for the night club and once for the Brunch/Sunday's a Drag Show.

As a club I would give it 4 stars.  The interior is lovely with fabric walls and decor that makes me think of old Hollywood ... but I shouldn't be surprised, because from what I hear that is very Harry (Denton).
